review: Installation was easy, but as I've read from other reviewers, I've only seen it work well on YouTube videos. The Chrome casting add-on to Chrome is sketchy at best. It seems as if this unit gobbles a lot of wireless bandwidth which, in turn, degrades the video and audio quality of both the PC and the TV as you translate it to the large screen.If you want good quality audio and video going from your laptop or PC to the TV, either pick up an HDMI/VGA/DVI cable and combine it with an audio patch cable, or even better yet, re-purpose an older computer and use that as part of your entertainment system.Good luck to you.

review: Basically it's a cheaper Roku that you need another device to use with.  I bought this hoping I could use it to view on TV programs that are not available on Roku's Hulu Plus or episodes from TV channels (such as CBS) that don't share their episodes with Roku.No luck.  ChromeCast does have a feature that allows you to cast what is on your browser window to the TV screen, so theoretically I could watch those episodes that way.  But it works so badly it's unwatchable.  It's still in the Beta version, though,, so maybe they'll improve it.  Just like they got around to improving their "voice recognition" captioning that has been in beta for years.  Oh, wait, they didn't.
